I've been searching for a hotel that is both on the 'recommended' list for my parent corporation and feels safe and not weird when you walk the corridors upstairs. 6 Columbus is the best I've found, and I'm going back next week for another stay.It is well located near the Park, near multiple subway lines, and near restaurants. If you walk west you find old style New York inexpensive lunch places, and across the street at the mall there are high end restaurants galore. Or you can go a few doors down for decent sushi. I had an excellent breakfast at the hotel's small cafe, too.The room was totally adequate and comfortable. Biggest complaint was the totally broken window and roller shade in my room. Maintenance came quickly to close it after it flew open, but it needed real attention, which it never received during my stay. But at least it had a way to bring in fresh air, rather than being hermetically sealed or only openable to 2 inches...My one complaint was the dearth of doormen and clerks - the staffing was light or busy elsewhere, especially the door staff. I used to stay at the Mondrian Soho frequently and appreciated the uniformly available and helpful staffing.

Stayed: December 2012.Pros:- Room is modern & clean.- Pleasant smelling soap, shampoo & conditioner provided.- Bathroom floor is heated.- Friendly & helpful staff.- Great location.- Comfortable queen bed.- Safety deposit box provided.Cons:- Room is small.- No tea/coffee facilities.- No free Wifi or gym.

I come to NYC at least once a year and stay at 6 Columbus. You can't beat the location or the staff! Always super friendly and eager to help. Our room was very clean and the balcony was massive. See you soon 6 Columbus!

This hotel is the perfect combination of price (for NYC) and location and that is its greatest asset. The front desk staff is very professional and friendly. The rooms are a little faded with things like a worn-through carpet and bad lighting. Overall a good choice for NYC with Central Park just across the street. Our room was next to a large ventilation unit. I didn't mind as white noise helps me sleep but that isn't the case for everyone.

Stayed here twice in two years. Everything far exceeded my expectations. The staff was friendly and courteous, and the rooms were very clean. The location can't be beat. Will definitely stay here again!

Super small rooms, even for New York, with only a bed and no other real furniture. Thin walls and you hear everything outside the room because the bed is only 2 feet from the door. I have mistakenly stayed here 3x and always end up in a queen room that seems smaller than any queen bed I've ever been in. They also don't make the beds with a fitted and flat sheet, so you are left with just a comforter. Which is a sign of how cheap they are.

Stayed here for one night on a couple of weekends ago. We arrived on an early flight on a Saturday morning and weren't expecting to get a room at 9am, so we were pleasantly surprised when the front desk gave us a room right away. We went to our room to drop our bags and found out that the downside of getting a room at 9am is that it was on the 2nd floor and it had no windows. The room was tiny, the carpet has seen better days and had stains all over it and dust was everywhere. We spent the day out and came back in the evening to find the floor of the 2nd floor completely covered in trash and a foul smell. The hotel lobby was very crowded because it hosts the entrance to the Japanese restaurant, which makes for some confusion as there's always people waiting for their table in the restaurant lobby (I've been to the restaurant many times on previous visits to nyc so this wasn't a surprise).Overall, the only nice thing about this place was the front desk, the valet service and a great Columbus circle location. The hotel structure is in dire need of a serious upgrade, not only the carpet, but the bathrooms and furniture as well. This was probably a cool hotel 15 years ago, but not anymore.
user_name:
spdmatos
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Stayed here for two nights and attended three Met operas in the Lincoln center. It was safe to walk from the Lincoln center to this hotel alone even in the midnight hours.The room we had was a large street facing room on the 11th floor. It had a balcony with floor to ceiling glass door and windows. The Mandarin Oriental Hotel one block away has outstanding restaurants and Spa service. Frick Collection and Met museum are all within walking distance.I love the location of this hotel.

For me, the hotel is more like 3 and a half stars, but the location is 4 and a half......The lobby is small and service was good. Fast. not particularly friendly. The hallways need a make-over, they are dark-ish and my floor - on 6th, worn.The rooms are small BUT Clean! and that's a big plus. Bed was ok. Not the best, but not uncomfortable. I felt like overall it was a boutique hotel, but the following night I stayed at the Parker Meridien and there was no comparison really.... just an extremely well run, excellent hotel. 6 Columbus was good, just not great.

I hate to admit it but we Pricelined and got this hotel. Had no idea what to expect. It looks a little worn out on the outside but it has a few great things going for it.1. Location is EXCELLENT. Right next to a major subway hole and on the SW corner of Central Park.2. There is a Starbucks right next door.3. The rooms are VERY clean and VERY nice -- just a bit small.4. Peter the doorman/bellhop/concierge/all around good guy. I would come here just because of him.No fitness center and not a lot of frills. But it is an EXCELLENT value and very boutiquey!

From the moment that I booked this hotel reservation, they were ready to be there with anything that we needed. I wanted to pre-pay the stay because it was a gift to my daughter and her husband for their anniversary. Eliseo Alvarez, Front Office-Assistant Manager went above and beyond to be accommodating to me prior to their stay. They loved the hotel-raved about how beautiful it was and how well situated the location was for their stay. Their room had a wonderful view, great space in the room, especially for NYC! Everything was top notch!Thank you, Eliseo and everyone who helped make their stay so special!

Stayed here for 5 nights in mid-March. Firstly, this hotel is fine... but just fine. It appears as a 4 star hotel on booking sites, but I have stayed in many hotels and this is arguably nearer a 3 star hotel. I don't dispute they probably have more lavish rooms than their POD or Queen rooms, but ultimately this just means you get a 3 star room in a 4 star hotel if you select these rooms. Hotel lobby is exceptionally dark and I can't really understand the ambience that they are going for. It was easy to feel thoroughly depressed at the lack of natural light in the hotel so you would think that they would paint the walls a more neutral colour rather than black lobbies and dark blue walls in the corridors. Also, the room doors in this hotel seem to slam incessantly. You would think that in a 4 star hotel they would dampen the doors, but it was common to hear doors opening and shutting at the other end of the corridor during the nightFirst night we were placed in room 99, a pod room. It was a well appointed room and on first inspection was decent for the price paid (£100 per night on priceline). Given the price the room was acceptable, but would no way pay the rack rate that they advertise on their own website. My first impressions were quashed when the 10ftx10ft massive unit (air conditioner?) on the adjacent building kicked in and sounded like a jet engine stirring up every 30 minutes. Not exactly 4 star! We requested a room change, but the hotel was full and this could not be honoured until the following day. We were moved as promised the very next day.Nonetheless, hotel staff were polite and helpful. Location of this hotel is excellent and well situated for the subway and other midtown Manhattan hotspots. If you can get a good deal on this hotel it worth a look. But frankly, I could have had a deal for only £15 more a night at the Hyatt with a city view and I would probably go for that next time as a safe hotel bet.Not a bad hotel all-in-all, but only if you can get at a low price. Otherwise, there are better to be had in NYC.

This hotel is conveniently located steps from Columbus Circle and Central Park. Like many NYC hotels the rooms are very small but they are designed to make the most of the space.The front desk staff was very helpful and friendly.

First of all, this hotel is in a great location for exploring the city. Easy walking distance to much of the city, and several subway lines right across the street. The staff were generally friendly, though the desk clerk said he'd call when my room was ready and never did. The room was as tiny as expected, but there were other issues. TV worked only intermittently, iPod docking station/clock did not work, toilet made strange noises, lots of noise from the hallway and air shaft my room faced, and internet service was not working for part of one day. That being said, the front desk offered to change my room on the second day, and I was upgraded to a huge room on a high floor with a street view. Front desk and bell staff were very nice. Might stay here again if I could get a good rate on a larger room.

I was under-awed by the size of our room 220 sq ft - an upgrade because it was my birthday. The view was - Well there was no view. BUT the bed, linens and towels were top notch. The pillows - perfect. Bathroom floor heated and robes supplied. maid service excellent and lobby staff helpful with directions. Our cable did not work the 1st 2 nights so we got free wifi and movies. NY Times supplied when requested. Great location. Whole Foods and subway across the street. We were happy with the hotel once we got over the size of the room and the view was not all that important....

When arriving in the room, everything looked ok. That's when disaster struck. Rude customer service and inept hotel staff. I had an issue with the toilet not refilling. The manager came and looked at it, did nothing, and said it was fine. This required an additional trip to the customer service desk where my room was changed, which should have happened the first time. The changed room was smaller, perhaps in retaliation? Terrible hotel, do not recommend.

Two nights I stayed in a small studio which was perfect for one person. I stayed an additional two nights upgrading to their large studio with a view of Central Park and Columbus Circle. the rooms were very quiet and the small studio had a heated bathroom floor that was appreciated. The beds in both rooms were very comfortable. This cozy hotel is directly across west 58th Street from the Columbus Circle Mall. Really well situated.

Finally getting round to writing up some previous trips - stayed at 6 Columbus for a few nights during last visit to North America, a couple of years back (September 2011).The plus points: friendly, helpful staff (good restaurant and nightlife recommendations, and help with directions/tickets); the streetside bar is buzzing and Above 6 is a worthy addition to the NYC roottop bar trend; great sushi in the inhouse restaurant (which is open late); brilliant location, effectively on SW corner of Central Park.The bad stuff: got to the hotel to be told that the room reserved wouldn't be available until the following day, as someone had decided to extend their stay and subsequently got stuck in a room not much bigger than a broom cupboard. I'm not sure that giving away a reserved room to someone else on the fly is accepted practice, but it didn't seem right. Got upgraded for the remainder of the stay to compensate - very good corner suite - but disingenuous first impression already left. Also got charged for mini-bar purchases which didn't happen, no response at all to multiple emails to the hotel and only refunded when email sent to the chief exec of the company (not a massive issue, more the principle of it). I note the 6 Columbus has changed hands since 2011, so hope these minor points have fallen away since then.On balance, would give 6 Columbus another go on returning to Manhattan.

The hotel room was small but then it was offered at a very competitive rate; so no complaints The hotel is clean, as are the rooms. The staff are very welcoming and pleasant, notably reception and the doormen. Well worth staying here.

Great location, one block south of central park. Bus and subway access right across the street. NIce rooms. The queen size bed room was a little small and only one chair to sit on. Used bed to sit most of the time. Bed was comfortable for sleeping. Tub/shower a little cramped for me. Staff was very nice and Peter the door man was great. I would avoid the restaurant adjoining the Hotel, overpriced. Nice restaurant/bar next to the hotel called the Coliseum. Good food and service reasonably priced drinks for the area.I would recommend 6 Columbus Hotel.

Stayed 4 nights and found the hotel and staff very welcoming. Rooms well appointed, clean and bright. The hotel is in a great location and the subway is just across the road. Will return the next time I'm in NYC

This hotel has a very dark, cold feel to it. We were "upgraded" to a King room but even then we got a room with a view of an air duct. The room was small, the carpet was worn, and the furnishings looked really outdated and very basic. That being said, the bed was comfortable and the room was quiet. I ended up sleeping very well. If you're visiting NY and just want a place to drop your stuff and will really only be sleeping there, this place would be ok. It's conveniently located. But if you like a pretty hotel with some reasonable amenities, this hotel is probably not for you.

I go to NYC frequently for both work and fun. I love staying in proximity of Columbus Circle, because it is so convenient to Central Park, shopping on 5th, and dining/entertainment on the western half of the city (HK, Chelsea, SOHO). It is a very convenient location. This was my first time staying at 6 Columbus. I was impressed. I only stayed one night, so I was not able to use all of the amenities of the hotel. Coffee shops, drug stores, liquor stores, are all within a one block walk. Vibe: This hotel has a great look. I would not considerate it luxurious, but it is hip and efficient. It is small, and in the perfect location. The location of the hotel makes it. This is NOT a family-oriented hotel.Service: I walked into the hotel in the morning from a terrible flight into LGA. The front desk upgraded my room, and found me an available room for immediate check in. When I called for ice, I received a knock on my door within 5-minutes. The front desk/concierge team knows the area well, and is very helpful with recommendations. Security is excellent, and polite - there are not 200 partiers making a scene trying to get to the bar. The entire staff was wonderful.Room: Small, modern, and efficient - think a large cruise ship room. The room was larger than other hotels in the neighborhood. I was in a Queen. Fantastic selection of in-room snacks/drinks. Wonderful bedding, bath products, and bath hardware. The shower was amazing. Heat and water were perfect (January stay). No view, but I was not concerned with that. The hotel has a roof-top deck/bar. Immaculately clean room. High style.Common areas: The hotel is showing a bit of age, but it is not disconcerting. Elevators were fast, which is rare in this neighborhood. Some wall paper is tattered, grout dirty, paint scraped, etc. Most travelers would not notice it. Summary: I enjoyed staying at 6 Columbus, and look forward to staying here again. I would book this hotel for a one or two night stay, but not if I had a full week of meetings. The staff is superb and the rooms are in great condition. Many modern hotels in NY have been "Rock Starred Out." My room was not, and in perfect condition. I enjoyed my stay. Thank you 6 Columbus!
user_name:
Visiting20001
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: No kettle, tea or coffee to fight the 10'F cold spell. Room temperature stayed at under 60F and could not respond to higher setting. Shower drain got blocked the third night. Had to pack and move to another (even smaller) room the night before next day check out. First room faced a brick wall. Second room faced another wall with big pipes. Rooms tiny. No space to open luggage. Narrow gap between wall and bed becomes hazardous because of a protruding drawer handle under the bed hidden under the duvet (see photo). My leg was cut each time I walk pass it.No wi-fi in room. Even our own 3G connection went slow in room.Could have rated lower if not for the good location, friendly porter and cleanliness of the rooms.

We booked last minute and got a great deal. Night away from kids in the city - room was small, but very sufficient. Like the added touch of radiant heat in bathroom floors. Bathroom otherwise was roomy and well appointed.The bed was firm with great quality sheets and comforter -- all cotton. Good widescreen TV.Didn't take advantage of it, but was happy to see a Blue Ribbon Sushi restaurant in the lobby. Awesome sushi!Perfect hotel for short NYC stay with excellent access to all midtown.Car valet overnight was convenient and $45. They were happy to hold both our bags and car after checkout.

Spent the night in NYC with my wife. We stayed in a studio suite. Room was large . Clean and well appointed. Great views and porch Only downside was the king size bed was a futon bed and the heating system was very noisy. Overall it was ok, but as it advertised as a luxury suite We expected a more comfortable bed

I have stayed in 6 Columbus Hotel many times (and each time I usually stay at least 7-10days)because the company I work in gives me two hotel choices, and this seems to be a better one for me personally due to its convenient location. It's right opposite the Time Warner Building and there is also a Starbucks and supermarket right next to the hotel so it's good for someone like me who cannot be bothered to go out to eat sometimes after a long day of work. 6 Columbus used to be a hip and stylish boutique hotel but I guess after so many years since it's opened, it's kind of worn down and it's not that cool anymore compared to a lot of other boutique hotels in town. Their rooms smell sometimes and they are very small for its price (then again, it's New York). They use branded amenities which is nice and one would feel being pampered. Unfortunately, their housekeeping seems to have their own cleaning and restocking system - one day your amenities or mini bar get refilled, one day it doesn't. I tried to explain these situations to the receptionist a few times in separate occasions but since it had not helped so far so I just couldn't be bothered anymore especially after a day of tiring work. However, it also means that I'll have to spend extra time to check my bills every time I check out.The receptionist are not particularly helpful or informative either, but must say they are presentable appearance wise. One thing I must give to this hotel is that their bellboys are very friendly and helpful. Since I usually travel with big suitcases and have to meet different customers from one location to another, the bell boys have been super friendly and helpful fetching me cabs (it can be very difficult at peak hours), carrying my suitcases etc. I really think they deserve a raise coz honestly if not because of their service, I would have requested my company to change to another hotel for me long time ago!O, their bar can get quite noisy on a Friday night and weekend! So watch out if you want some quietness.

The good- room was clean, well equipped and location is great. The bad- I got a room with a window to a chimney. I asked the staff for help twice (regarding transportation etc') and they were useless. For the cost of the room it was very disappointing.

This boutique hotel is perfectly located above a top notch Sushi bar with Central Park and Time Warner out the front door. The small scale gives staff a chance to get to know you and your needs. I left my laundry bag in my room and they tracked me down at my office to ask what I'd like them to do. Very nice! They need to stay on top of the room decor as the wear and tear of a top hotel is starting to show around the edges.

This boutique hotel is in the perfect location for access to shopping, Central Park, and entertainment at City Center, Carnegie Hall, and Lincoln Center. It’s about a 10 block walk to Times Square for Broadway Shows. Feeling energetic, we walked the 20+ blocks to the Metropolitan Museum of Art (80th Street and Fifth Avenue) and back, and lived to write this review.The room we had was a deluxe king room with 350 sq. ft. of space and a window looking out upon 58th Street, directly across from the Time Warner Center. As a matter of fact we could see people working in their offices day and night. The lower floors of the Time Warner Center contain shops, with restaurants on the higher floors. Our room was absolutely fabulous.The room comes equipped with a king sized bed and is very comfortable. There is a clock radio on the window side of the bed with the phone on the other side. There are wall mounted lights on either side of the bed. Also on the window side, I noticed a box built into the wall, containing several magazines. I didn’t get a chance to read those - after all, it was New York City.The bathroom is spacious (for NYC) and contained a white bathrobe hanging on the inside of the door, along with an iron in its bag. The hotel furnished 2 large bath towels, 2 hand towels, and 2 wash cloths. Atop the commode tank were 2 glass containers, one filled with cue tips, the other filled with cotton balls (did not have any need for those). Skin care products furnished by the hotel were Ren Clean Skincare, Neroli and Grapefruit Body Cream, and Crème Corps Fleurs D’Oranger et Pamplemousse, Ren Pro-Vitamin Conditioner, and Apres-Shampoing Pro-Vitamine.The closet in the corner near the window contained an umbrella for guest use and a safe at the bottom of the closet. There were plenty of hangers. Near the closet, at the window, were 2 chairs and a table. As you enter the room, there is a full length mirror on the wall to your left. Beyond the mirror is a writing desk and chair. Beneath the desk is the mini-fridge and above the desk is the 40” sized TV screen facing the bed.The service in this hotel is outstanding and I wholeheartedly recommend it for your next visit to NYC. Tip: There are 2 pullout drawers built into the bed for storing your belongings. We didn't notice those until we looked under the covers.

This was a great hotel, although we did get upgraded on the second day to a big room with balcony which made the experience much better. The first room was quite cramped, although still functional. The staff were friendly and helpful.The hotel is very close to central park, a whole foods within a shopping mall and so many bars and restaurants it's hard to pick where to go.

A small boutique hotel close to Central Park with friendly service. Decor is nicely done. Japanese restaurant on the ground floor was very, very good, but a bit too loud. We first was given a standard room, with a window with an inside view. Sort of like looking into an elevator shaft with a pipe runs through the middle. Daylight from the opening high above. Below is an abyss. The bed in the standard room was Tokyo sized double. It's standard length, but significantly narrower than regular double. They should have installed railings on both sides. Ended up we had to pay more to move up to a room with king bed. This studio room with a relatively large terrace was very spacious and comfortable. Terrace has all the loungers, chairs and table we need, yet still enough space to walk around. Bathroom was also very spacious with a full deep tub. They have the same contoured toilet seat that we are accustomed to - it feels just like home.

We were shown to a "standard" room, reserved for $400/night. Small even by NYC standards with a double bed that was ok for midgets in love but we're regular sized people in love. The window looked onto a light shaft with a tiny opening many floors up, so basically no light, no air, and no view.After complaining, we got, for $100 extra, a three-times bigger room with a giant terrace populated by a couple of large lounge chairs and a table-and-4-chairs--with lots of room to spare on the terrace. King bed with tons of floor space and big bathroom, with a tub large enough to do laps in--ok, maybe I exaggerate slightly. So your view of this hotel will depend on whether you feel ripped off to be in a closet for $400/night, or whether you are enjoying a palatial suite for $500/night. Clearly it improved for us in the second room, but I would not stay in this hotel unless I could be sure of getting it. I would, however, be happy with one of the tiny rooms if I had been travelling on my own.The sushi resto--The Blue Ribbon--was loud, but the sushi was among the best I've ever had--and I've explored Japan as well as the west coast of North America. Also a great selection of beer. It's a class act. It was open till 0200 on the Saturday night we went there, and was busy from 0030-0145 which is when we wanted to have dinner.The hotel staff was impeccably friendly and helpful.

Standard "boutique-y" NYC hotel. Clean, but cramped room. Spartan furnishings and worn in places. Location is excellent, and the world class Blue Ribbon sushi is just off the lobby. Good choice for a reasonably priced, well located midtown stay - especially if it is for only a couple of nights.

I've stayed here before when I needed to be central to NY Fashion Week and my clients' showrooms, and always appreciated the location (Whole Foods is right across the street, and a 24-hr drugstore is next door) and thought the hotel was pretty good. But my most recent visit has been disappointing - first I had to switch rooms to get a room with a desk...and then the desk had no chair. And then the chair they brought me didn't fit. So they brought some beaten up wooden chair from god knows where that juuuuust fits...but def not a comfortable work set up. The room phone is damaged (I had to call downstairs from my cell), the tv lost sound for about an hour last night, there's no gym or affiliation with nearby gyms, I'm facing a wall...it's just not worth the $400-$500+ per night I'm paying. I cancelled the rest of my reservation and am moving to another hotel mid-trip - not the most convenient situation, but I can't stomach what I'm getting vs what I'm paying when there are so many great hotels in the city.

The staff was very helpful and the location is excellent for exploring Central Park and other parts of Manhattan. I was upgraded to a slightly larger room with two double beds, but since I was traveling alone for business I didn't need the extra bed and it took up most of the "extra" space in the room. The size of the room was on par with other NY hotels, but the door didn't close all the way without some force and the room felt a little shabby. They do have an excellent rooftop bar, with retractable ceiling so it's usable year-round and the sushi restaurant in the lobby is pretty good. If I had to stay in Columbus Circle I'd stay here again, but otherwise there are better hotels in other parts of the city that I would look to first.

My mother and I stayed at 6 Columbus over the Columbus Day Weekend, each in our own room. We were each upgraded for free to higher floors, which are bigger rooms, which was amazing as we were first timers to this hotel and to the Thompson hotels group. She was upgraded to the 11th floor (floor 11 has only four rooms) which had a large bedroom with a closet and desk and the most comfortable bed she had ever had in a hotel, and my mom has travelled all over the world. There was also a lovely big marble bathroom. Room was modern style but comfortable and roomy, and there were windows on both sides of the bedroom and one in the bathroom--it was on the back of the hotel and was super quiet. My room was the 12th floor two story Columbus Loft, which has an open plan kitchen/living room with a full marble bath off the kitchen, with a remote operated gas fireplace with a 60-inch flatscreen over it! the living room portion is double height, and there are private stairs up to the king bedroom and gigantic marble clad bathroom, with a steam shower big enough for even the most confirmed claustrophobic (with a window so you can watch the sky while you shower), a huge separate soaking tub, double sinks and the toilet in a separate windowed area inside the bathroom. The king bed was incredibly comfortable with high end linens and a flat screen perfectly positioned for viewing from the bed. The entire suite had floor to ceiling windows which were sparkling clean so as to be able to enjoy the views of Columbus Circle, the sky, and a peek of Central Park and the East Side beyond. For those who like a dark room to sleep, the room has been smartly appointed with easy to operate privacy screen shades and blackout curtains. There were three easily accessible and available outlets under the desk and there were several in the bathrooms and there may have been more, I did not bother looking. There are two Juliet balconies off the living room, too. As for service, I was incredibly Impressed with everyone I encountered. Three different bellmen helped us over the course of our stay, with luggage, directions, taxis, etc-- even going that extra bit to run us down one a block away and holding it there for us. The front desk was great with directions and quick checkins and checkouts--I saw them helping a traveler with his difficult checkin for a foreign flight first on a computer then making a series of phone calls to get the job done. We did not eat dinner in the sushi restaurant but we had drinks there Saturday night after the opera and the bartenders handled the hip (and hungry, dinner til 2 am) crowd with charm and aplomb. We were there Sunday morning for the delicious and very well priced breakfast. My only complaints were that the bottled water in the room was all part of the mini bar program, I feel in NYC a small complimentary bottle on the nightstand is a nice touch. On the other hand, there is a Duane Reade (a division of Walgreens) operating 24/7 just outside the front door, so this is a problem easily sorted out. In short, we had a terrific stay in a very clean hotel, we had amazing service and I highly recommend 6 Columbus.

Its supossed to be a hip hotel remodeled but it seemed like a 60 hotel lost in time to me. The room carpet was old, they should be changed urgently. Decoration is ok but dark and not fancy. The room size is big for NYC. Not a hotel for babies. There is no ramp at the front door and doormen never helped me with the Stroller they just looked as I struggled with my stroller to get in. They even said it was too much work our luggage. Service was terrible. Location is great but I ve stayed at the Hudson hotel that is in the same block much more cheaper and much more modern design and beautiful rooms (though might be smaller) we went one night through hotel tonight donut was ok but I wouldn't spend that money in the hotel I won't go back

I've read reviews saying this hotel is not kid-friendly, and while it certainly doesn't have a family vibe we had a good 4-night stay in a King Suite with our two kids (13 and 15). The four of us had dinner at the sushi restaurant downstairs and it was great -- though noisy. Our room was clean and comfortable and we found the entire staff to be extremely pleasant and helpful at all times. My only issue with the King Suite is that it provides no storage. There is a very, very small free-standing wardrobe that barely fits in the tiny bedroom (you can't even open the wardrobe door without closing the bedroom door) and other than that there is essentially zero storage. We had four people and NOT ONE drawer (except for the tiny drawers of the bedside tables in the bedroom, which would accommodate a couple of hairbrushes). The "living" area of the Suite is, unlike the bedroom, quite roomy, and could EASILY accommodate a chest of drawers on either side of the fold-out sofa, or even another, larger wardrobe. The bathroom is also very small for a King Suite -- just one very, very small sink, and again -- no storage. Not a drawer, not a shelf, nothing. So the stuff of four people ends up on the countertop. With our two kids having to live entirely out of suitcases and my husband and I unable to put most of our stuff away, the drawback of the room was that we were constantly walking over each other's stuff. I wish the hotel would reconsider they way they've furnished these rooms.

Our rate for three nights ranged between $475-$522 for a deluxe room with two queen beds. Pros: Good location; subway entrance right across the street; quiet room; comfortable beds; soothing shower; helpful, personable staff working the front door; delicious Japanese food in the restaurant; fun, modern decor.Cons: The room was very tiny with not much space for moving around; only place to sit was on beds; a couple of small, squished bugs between the glass and mat on a painting on one of the walls (meant to alert staff to this but forgot ... Room 58); not too many plugs if two people need to charge devices.

Our 1st out of 4 hotels during our 2 weeks stay in NYC. The room is small but functional. Right across the road from Time Warner Center with Whole Foods in the basement and Per Se on the 4th. Drugstore just around the corner.

I stayed at 6 Columbus for work, and while the mention of the name gets New Yorkers excited, I found the hotel to be quite average. (Bar the service, which was poor). The hotel is one of those that ticks all the boxes, and yet doesn't stand out of deliver anything particularly well. So i cannot fault it, but cannot rave about it either. My trip was for work, and I missed having a desk, the closet was tiny(so luckily was on my own) and the service poor. (Front desk not prepared to book a taxi, weren't proactive. All just a veneer of service. I'm learning, though that this is the best you can hope for in New York. And the location is of course perfect for the park. .

clean rooms. everything is brand new. comfy beds. we enjoyed the breakfast. very good service and polite. really good prices. i dont get it why this hotel has bad reviews. the location is really good too!

We booked at 6 Columbus because of the Thompson name and the fantastic location. Unfortunately that's all we got. The lipstick on this pig is mediocre at best. Not sure which 1st year interior design student designed the lobby, "refurbished" old rickety elevators, hallways and rooms but hey, if they turned the lights down, maybe it would work. The walls are paper thin and we were lucky enough to have a party next door to us all hours of the day. A dozen calls to the front desk didn't help and the manager was completely apathetic. The sushi restaurant in the lobby and rooftop is the saving grace. Wouldn't stay here again.

As with other Thompson Hotels, this hotel is great - location, restaurant and roof top all amazing. If you are looking for a nice hotel, with good sized rooms (for NYC) that is close to Central park and walking distance to Time Square I highly recommend staying at 6 Columbus.

This hotel is in a great location off of Columbus Circle and is very convenient to the 1 Subway Line and the park entrance. There is also the mall right there if you need anything. It was a little difficult to actually find since I thought that the address was 6 Columbus Circle, so pay attention to the directions when getting there! It was clean and modern with a comfortable bed and updated decor and amenities. Nice hot shower and fluffy towels! The staff were all very friendly and helpful if I had questions about the area. I would definitely stay here again for travel.

OK first off -- CONS:As other travellers have reported: rooms are very small, which is normal for Manhattan. But they are well-appointed. It's an old hotel with a cool facelift, so the doors aren't thick enough to cancel out noise of other guests. We heard a knock-down girl fight in our hallway at 3 am and called the front desk to report it. The next day they comped are internet (which I hate that you have to pay for) for our inconvenience, which was nice, but we had to ask.PROS:The lobby has great music and the restaurant downstairs was awesome. We had booked through Tablet and had our breakfast included.The location is right by the entrance to a major subway stop under the Time Warner building. You can catch lines to just about anywhere from here, which is fantastic. The southwest corner of Central Park is a two minute walk away, and all of Midtown is yours to explore on foot here.Overall a totally great stay for the price and location.

Great location on Columbus circle, near broadway and very close to Central Park.Rooms however were extremely small, even for NY especially considering the hotel is touted as luxury..the air conditioning was very fickle aswell, requiring resets aswell as blocked toilets on arrival.Staff were very helpful however, helping to suggesting restaurants across NY.As with all hotels in NY the wifi was not free and was very expensive ($15 a day!) but lobby wifi was free so not the worst..Overall a good stay for location but would not stay again as the cost isn't justified given the extremely small and relatively unmodernised rooms.

This is the second time I'm staying at 6 Columbus. The last time was very good - the room, queen bed, was terrific yet rather small (as most NYC hotels are). I loved the location and the retro design. This stay was over the top! We got upgraded to the suite (the loft) which is an amazing two floors, 2 bathrooms, king-bed room with a kitchenette and a dining area. It was spectacular. Every small thing we asked for (coffee for the coffee maker for example) was taken care of quickly. The bell boys and reception desk were extremely answering our needs (crib for the baby, parking questions) and overcoming a technical issue (the keys machine broke just minutes before we've arrived so they had to get us in the room). The location is the best - Upper West Side, just behind Columbus circle - where we got excellent food for a picnic at the park (thanks to an amazing Whole Foods branch), right on the edge of Central Park. It was the perfect place for the business/family trip we had. I think we've found our regular place in NYC - I'll be returning for sure. Maybe next time I'll try the sushi place the the hotel - I heard it was terrific.

On a recent overnight in Manhattan I stayed at this hotel; arriving late on a Tuesday evening the restaurant was hopping but not completely jammed. The rooftop deck had a great view and nice drinks (and the sushi was quite good; as was the oxtail fried rice.)Rooms were NY sized -- mine had two beds and little room for anything else. Would have been a challenge with a family but as a solo overnight was just fine.Efficient, quiet, comfortable. Great overall experience.

Very nice hotel. Rooms small but neat and clean. Staff helpful and attentive. Has roof top bar. Restaurant served a nice breakfast. Near park and train. More on tbe trendy side nice young crowd. Good safety features

The staff at this hotel go above and beyond. This boutique doesn't make you feel intimidated. You feel welcome the very moment you walk in.This hotel is 30 seconds from Central Park. The Time Warner bldg is right across the street. Duane Reade is right next door. A $12 cab ride to midtown..It was great knowing we had an amazing place to sleep after a crazy nite out!I'll definitely stay gain!!!!!

This was the first trip to New York for my daughter and I so we wanted a hotel that was close to everything but not necessarily in the thick of things6 Columbus was perfect for that, close to all the New York sights but far enough away from the bustle of the streets. Central Park was just across the street and a great place to chill out in such a busy city. The staff were very accomodating and helpful especially the doormen. The Japanese restaurant in the hotel was fantastic, best Japanese food we have ever eaten. The room was clean and the bed super comfy but the size of the room was the only downside for us. After 10 days in New York with 2 women shopping up a storm we found we were always tripping over bags. Apart from that I would recommend this hotel

Great people, great service, ideal location - centrally located, easy access to transpo (both foot and underground) and energetic without being a scene. As a NYC native this is where I stay whenever I'm back in town. Tip: I think anyone who orders room service for breakfast in NYC is nuts - EXCEPT at 6 Columbus. They do a great job!

I'm a frequent business traveler to NY and I decided to try this hotel because of its convenient Columbus Circle location. Sadly it appears to be yet another one of those pretentious, trendy looking but completely unpractical hotel. I was in a Superior King room which is a mid to high grade room of this hotel. The room is small - which is fine - I've stayed in plenty of small hotel rooms in NYC and Tokyo as long as the design is smart and use the space effectively. Unfortunately, the design here is completely flawed. There was only one chair in the room and when pulled up to the desk, one cannot get through the room from one side to the other because it backs right up to the foot of the bed. There was no desk lamp and the lighting overall was so bad that it will make working at night impossible. I went on the website and looked at some pictures and noticed most rooms have desk lamp, so I called for one. They delivered a desk lamp that was so huge that it wouldn't fit on the already very small desk! The bathroom was very spacious but then again the design was flawed. The tub was so narrow and instead of having a curved shower rod which most hotels have these days to enlarge the shower space, it comes with a straight one right over the edge of the tub, making it simply claustrophobic to take a shower plus there is no way to NOT touch the curtain or the wall. The mirror over the sink was so high that I could barely see my chin, making it also impossible to see and blow dry my shoulder length hair. I'm short - 5'3" - but THAT short. When I returned from dinner, the room smelled like smoke - apparently through the AC vent as someone must be smoking somewhere in the hotel. When I went to set my alarm, I found out that the clock was completely broken - no wonder the time on it was wrong! It was just one thing after another that made by typical,supposedly business-as-usual stay uncomfortable and unpleasant. The Thompsons Hotels website looks so intriguing that I was looking forward to this stay and was hoping that I would find a new, boutique hotel chain to love. But sadly this falls far below my expectations.

Great location near Central Park. Convenient to 30 Rock, theaters, and Time Square. Average size room for NYC. Very clean. Comfortable bed. Lots of in-room amenities. Would definitely stay here again.

My hunny and I stayed here for a night just to get away from life for a night. We checked in with ease, we're upgraded to a beautiful king room, and enjoyed a day/night in the city. Directly across the street was amazing shopping, any train we needed, and Central Park was around the corner. The staff was excellent and I was impressed by how quickly any request we made was granted. I suggest this hotel to anyone looking for an excellent hotel in the city wanting beauty, cleanliness and convenience. You will def be seeing me there again!
user_name:
Ashley S
New York City, New York

review_body: Using the Hotel Tonight app on our iPhone, my wife and I chose this hotel. Conveniently located next to the Metro stop, right across the street from shopping and a Whole Foods, one block away from Central Park, four blocks from Lincoln Center...the list goes on.Check in was a breeze, and Lucille at the front desk was lovely and welcoming. There is a sushi restaurant and a rooftop bar onsite. We were given a Queen Deluxe room with a very comfortable bed and larger-than-average bathroom with nice amenities. Everyone that we encountered at this hotel was friendly and helpful.Honestly, I wish we could have stayed at this hotel for the week that we were in the city. If the price fits your budget, I recommend that you give 6 Columbus a try!

Stayed here for 2 nights this week after working the MLB All-Star game. I reserved a King Deluxe room about a week before arrival and used the 10% off deal the hotel offered through TripAdvisor. I arrived a little early (1:30pm) and my room (#31) wasn't ready so I stored my bags and walked around midtown for a few hours. When I got back, the bellman brought my bag up and asked if I needed a luggage rack (I said no, but in retrospect I should've said yes). I ended up just putting my bag on the desk which was fine. I thought there was plenty of room to maneuver around the bed and never felt cramped. One of my favorite parts was the little sitting area (a couple chairs and table) by the window which looked out onto 58th street (across from the TW Center) - a perfect perch for people watching. The bathroom was fine as well, sized well for the room. The only nitpick was that the sink was oriented 90 degrees to the left, so that kind of threw me the first few times. Seriously, not a huge deal but I remembered it. I didn't have a water problem like other reviewers but it is a low ledge getting into the shower so if you don't have the curtain the right way, I could see where there would be problems. The bed itself was firm, the chairs were comfy and there was never really much noise coming from either the hallway or the street - a couple times I heard sirens & trash trucks, but I wouldn't really call that "street noise" and I was just on the 3rd floor.I look at NYC like I look at Vegas - if you're spending very much time in your room, you're doing it wrong. For 6 Columbus, the selling point has to be location and what I would call "location-based amenities". First off, there's a Duane Reed (24-hr drugstore), a Starbucks, a Subway & a Dunkin' Donuts within 100 feet of the front door. The subway is directly across the street and the Columbus Circle stop seemed to have all the major trains. I didn't partake in the Blue Ribbon Sushi in the hotel but the reviews made it out to be one of the best in the city - the heat wave just didn't give me an appetite for sushi. I did try out the rooftop bar, Above 6 Columbus and it was fine - moderately priced drinks (glass of Macallan 12 for $16) and there were indoor and outdoor seating areas. Even with the heat, the outdoor area was nice and provided a view of the Circle. All the administrative bits of the hotel, check in and out, staff responsiveness, housecleaning and overall service were all above par with my other travels, so no complaints there. When I come back to NYC I will for sure greatly consider 6 Columbus for my stay and I say that just because who knows I may want to stay in a different part of town. For the Central Park area, the combination of value and accommodations were perfect for me this week.

Spent a long weekend in NYC for my cousin's wedding. This hotel is located at Columbus Circle and was relatively close to the church and conveniently close to the reception venue. I reserved a King Deluxe room about three weeks before my arrival. Upon my arrival (about 2pm), I was told the room wasn't ready as the room carpet was being shampooed. Checked in again later after 4pm and then again about 5:30pm and the room still was not ready. Finally, at 6:15pm I was given the key to the room. One of the bell men, Chris, helped bring the luggage up with us. We entered the room and immediately smelled an unnatural scent. In short, it was nasty (like vomit or urine). I went back to the front desk and spoke with the staff. They asked no questions and looked for another room. It took some time but they located another room. Unfortunately, there were no other king deluxe rooms so I was put into a queen deluxe. The room faced an interior area unlike the king deluxe which faced street. It was a little disappointing however still comfortable. But, the manager, Mark, made a concession the next day and was sincerely apologetic for the problem. Our stay coincided at the beginning of the HEATWAVE and the hotel AC worked perfectly. Throughout our entire stay, ALL of the staff were genuinely friendly.. When the concierge forgot to save me a Sunday NY Times newspaper (having my cousin's wedding notice), one of the bell men, Lawrence, set out and obtained one for me that evening. Every time we left and returned we were sincerely greeted. We felt very welcomed at the 6, a Thompson hotel. We would return again.

We recently stayed here for 8 nights whilst visiting friends in New York. We wanted to be on Upper Westside and got a great deal through Booking.com. When we arrived, the hotel had kindly given us a triple upgrade, meaning we stayed in a King Deluxe room. We were expecting a small room since we were in NYC, but our room was amazing. It was huge! It had a comfortable bed and spacious bathroom. We had a good view out towards Columbus Circle, but never heard any noise through the night. We used the hotel bar a few times, and although a little expensive, the staff were very friendly. We didn't eat in the restaurant so I cannot comment on this, but it did look to be very busy. The rooftop bar is an added bonus and is a nice way to spend a sunny evening. The only downside is the lack of fitness centre, although I can't say that we missed it that much! The location really is one of the best parts of this hotel - straight across from the subway station and easy walking to Central Park, 5th Avenue and Times Square. Throughout the week, we were left notes and gifts from the manager which was a nice touch too. From the housekeeping to the front desk staff, we were always greeted with a smile and a friendly chat. We can't wait to return to this hotel - we enjoyed every minute of it!

Stayed for two nights with my 12 year old niece. Got a great price thru Priceline. $100 off the rack rate. It's a small room in a small boutique hotel. That's what you have to expect in NYC and for a boutique hotel!! Beds were comfy. Huge TV. Nice sized bath with amazing shower! Close to the best diner in Manhattan, The Flame. Peter the doorman recommended this place and we gave it a try....returning the next morning for more!

Stayed at 6 Columbus for 6 nights. We typically stay downtown but because of a family reunion, We needed a hotel on the Upper West Side. Great location-- easy access to Central Park, the East side, subway stations. The hotel was what I had expected from the Thompson group. Modern decor and friendly staff. They were very nice to upgrade us from a Deluxe Queen to a Studio King for $75 and it was worth it!. The rooms in the deluxe queen or king are very very small. Good for 1 person but not 2. The studio king had a terrace and a sliver view of the park. Given that I'm familiar with NYC- I didn't feel the need to spend $880+ for a 5 star hotel. I would stay at 6 Columbus again and definitely in a Studio King.

I agree with the most recent review - my mum and I stayed in June 2013 for three nights, and the room was quite small but the bathroom was nice, clean and bright. The wardrobe wouldn't be big enough for a longer stay, and I'd recommend if you're staying longer than we did that you get a bigger room or stay somewhere else.The location is what this hotel is best for - right opposite the subway, the shops at the Time Warner Centre were great and I'd really recommend Landmarc, a restaurant on the 3rd floor - we went just after we arrived after a recommendation from a girl on the front desk. It was packed when we got there, but we were served super quickly and the food was great. Right next to Central Park and not far from all the sights, the location was perfect for visiting all the sights.I think it's kinda outrageous that they charge $15 a day for wifi when you can get free wifi next door at Starbucks and at most restaurants and places around the city.The guys on the door were really helpful, going the extra mile to get us a cab etc.Overall, mixed - but definitely check it out if you're only visiting for a short time and to see the major sites.

We booked into this hotel for 8 days. The room is, as reviewed by others, very small - there was no place to lay out our suitcases. There are drawers under the bed,however and you can put your suitcase just by the door....gives you enough room to walk around the bed. Internet connection was $15/day - and we were unable to use our cellphones to call locally unless we had paid the $15. There is no business centre to use a common wifi nor an excercise room ($45/day across the street). The upside of this hotel for us was that the staff were wonderful - friendly, helpful, efficient and knowledgeable. While the rooms were small, the bathrooms were lovely - fresh, bright, fabulous water pressure in the shower...made up for the close quarters of the main area, as far as we were concerned. The location is easy - suway across the street, Central Park a block away, MoMa 5 blocks....easy to get around. There is a Whole Foods in the mall across the street, so we could enjoy the veggie bar and hot foods buffet if we didn't feel like going out for a meal. We were out walking around town most of the day, so the size of the bedroom wasn't such a big deal, but if you are used to spaciousness, think this one through carefully.

Great location!!This little boutique hotel has renovated modern rooms, with nice stuff, and all the accomadation you need in a vacation in the big apple (where you are mostly out of the room).and again - Great location!! both quiet and close to central park and lincoln center!

It has it all - cool lobby, great bar, top restaurant, fantastic west side location, comfy beds, excellent style, and the best service of any hotel in NYC - so genuinely helpful and attentive. Must stay longer next time. No time to get to the gym so can't say more, but like everything else it was probably state of the art. Not sure about bringing the kids, very adult atmosphere.

Stayed here for 3 nights on short break. We arrived very late from London and check in staff was rather unhelpful. Anyway room was small but ok but the couple were very noisy and chain smokers. Bar on roof has nice views but there is not space up there and oddly half of the roof seems closed. Basically the place has no nice vibe it's cool to crash but that's about it. Spend a tad more and sty at standard hotel would be my advice.

Friendly staff; very good location near the Central Park; very easy to walk to best places in NY but subway is just in front. Rooms are a little bit small but beds are very comfortable and the shower is great.

We had a very nice stay here this past weekend, but it was ultimately spoiled by our experience at the front desk at checkout. The good: great location, most of the staff is very friendly and helpful, Blue Ribbon Sushi Bar and Grill was great, the room was comfortable and fine. Mark at the front desk was very good. The bad: This hotel charges $15 per day for wi-fi in 2013! On top of that, they indicate the $15 is for 24 hours, but don't really mean that. We checked in around 8:00 p.m. on Friday evening and checked out on Sunday and were informed by a borderline hostile front desk person that we were responsible for 3 days because that's "how they calculate it". We had to switch rooms during our stay because the air conditioning didn't work in our room (taking a chunk out of our day to pack and move, not to mention the time we spent in a hot room before that) and suggested maybe they could comp the wi-fi as compensation for that inconvenience, but no deal. It was a little embarrassing. After thinking about it and figuring the hotel would not really want a guest to leave unhappy about something this small, I asked to speak to the manager about it and he could not have cared less. It's a shame this happened, because we really did like the hotel.

We relocated here from the West Village and were more than happy with our stay. We used a discount website and got a terrific rate. The front desk knew this, and still upgraded us to a fabulous room on the 11th floor. The staff was super helpful and friendly. I loved walking out the door and seeing Central Park. What a treat!

From the moment I stepped through the door for my week stay, I was treated like everyone's cherished aunt. I arrived a couple of hours before the 3:00 p.m. check in time, but I was given a room right away. At the end of my stay, they didn't hesitate to extend my departure time by an hour. Every time I encountered a staff member, I was greeted with a smile and kind words. You know, that is so comforting for a woman traveling alone. Two days into my stay, I found a nice treat from the management left for me in my room. The housekeeping staff was top notch. The concierge was delightful. My room was small but standard for NYC. It was clean, the textiles were first rate including the bathrobe, which I always appreciate, and the toiletries were nice. I had a room in the back, and what it lacked in a view it more than made up for in peace and quiet. The location couldn't have been more perfect. Starbucks is next door, the subway is a few steps away across the street, and lots of great restaurants are nearby. I spent most of my time at Lincoln Center attending the two great New York ballet company performances, and it was a pleasant walk of just three blocks. I thoroughly enjoyed my week, and I hope to return to this charming hotel on future trips to NYC.

This hotel is a small and very friendly hotel located right at Columbus Circle at the SW corner of Central Park. Its a 10 minute walk to either Lincoln Center or Times Square, and the Columbus subway stop is directly across the street from the hotel serving the Broadway/7th Ave line and the 8th Ave line. (You can be in the Village in 10 minutes by 8th Ave express.) The neighborhood is mostly residential, so there are no crowds of tourists (as you would see in Times Sq) and there are numerous cafes and delis and restaurants within a block or two in any direction. We found the staff to take a personal interest in us and what we were there to do -- and they remembered and spoke to us each time we came through the lobby. There are only 9 rooms per floor, so no inside hallway noise, and there was no street noise in the room either due to the quiet neighborhood location. The rooms are large by NY standards, recently re-done and very comfortable and nicely decorated (60's decor). This is a place to stay to get a feel for actually "living" in New York City, while being convenient to everything by walking or subway or bus.

We stayed here for 4 nights and although there have been comments that the hotel is expensive, we were able to get a very good rate so I don't feel that the room was bad value for money. The sushi restaurant Blue Ribbon was a great find. We had an excellent meal there and I would highly recommend it. The location is quite good and the staff was very pleasant and helpful.As other reviewers have noted the rooms are small and the only common area is in front of reception so it can feel claustrophobic at times. The lifts are quite slow so we walked up and down most of the time. The beds are average. Some of the noise from the hallway carries through into the room.I think this hotel is fine for a short stay in NYC.

Near everything. Chic but not chilly. Smart if compact room. Terrific meal at the Blue Ribbon Sushi restaurant. By the way, room service breakfast actually worth the price. On the doorstep of Columbus Circle, Lincoln Center, Central Park.

Husband and I, along with other family were in NYC to celebrate our son's graduation from business school. We stayed 3 nights. There are a few things we enjoyed about this hotel, that are important to us, as travelers. First and foremost, the staff was very friendly and accomodating. We especially want to recognize Peter who was so attentive to our every need, always happy to help in any way he could and always inquiring as to what more he or the staff could do for us. Anything we needed, or any issue we had (1 minor, i.e. slow drain in bathroom) was taken care of promptly. We had a room with a king-size bed which was a little larger (not by much though) than the queen size the in-laws had. Many of the reviews here have comments about the size of the rooms...yes they are small and not much room for scooting by one another but we were out from early morning to late evening. If you are looking for a hotel room in which you want to 'hang out', then this is not it. If you want a nice, cozy, upscale room to come back to after a busy day then it's perfect. Tip: We asked for 2 of those little folding luggage racks to place our suticases on, as they were not items already in the room. This was more convenient than accessing the suitcases from the floor. Iron and Ironing board are also not in the room, but all you have to do is ask for them. everything was promptly delivered by housekeeping. This hotel gave us the feeling that we had our own private residence. Once we were in our room you didn't hear a thing. Yes the rooms could have better lighting, but again, it was very relaxing to come to at the end of the day. We never once heard a siren from the streets of New York...we slept great! The only reason I'm not able to give the hotel an 'excellent' rating is because of the experience we had at the rooftop bar, as well as the first floor bar and sushi restaurant. Although they may be seperately owned businesses within the hotel (we weren't sure) they are still part of the hotel 'experience' overall and we might have spent more time at each if the staff had not been as aloof and indifferent as they were. Much different attitudes than the front desk and concierge staff at the hotel.We would definitley stay here again, however.

There's not much to say about this hotel because there is so little to it. The rooms are dark and small, they charge a lot for them and there's a sushi resto as part of the complex. If I wanted sushi at the end of every day that would be great, but I tend to want a wider choice of things to eat. For a 'Thompson Hotel' you think they could try a little harder with the amenities, especially at $400 a night! Doesn't say a lot about brand. Staff were friendly and helpful. Location is great.

One of my clients uses 6 Columbus as her NYC hotel of choice so my stay this week was the third or fourth for me. I've been in plenty of Manhattan hotels and this is one of my favorites. I think it comes down to the smaller scale of the place. Because it doesn't have hundreds of rooms the vibe is cool. The guest doesn't encounter mobs of people there and because the staff doesn't either, service is top notch.The location is good--a subway stop across the street at the Time Warner Center(with shops aplenty), Starbucks right next door for beanheads, and Central Park a hop, skip and jump away.The rooms are comfortably chic, with New York minimalist style and form following function. Spacious, they are not, but pleasing nonetheless. They are decently sized by local standards.I had dinner in the hotel's Blue Ribbon Sushi Bar and Grill on an earlier visit and found that the meal was the winner that the name suggests. The bar is cozy. Japanese bottled beers abound.One caveat: infirmed guests should know that the front entrance has steps and no ramps. I'm sure that a hotel of this quality will be ably serve those with special needs but those accommodations would be something to consider.I'm hoping that business takes me back to 6 Columbus soon.

I stayed here for 2 nights mid-April. As a single female traveler, I am generally quite skeptical about where to stay. This was a very last minute stay but I don't regret it at all. The staff were very friendly and accommodating- especially with certain venues and things to do in the area. The location is simply fabulous! The rooms are a little bit small for my liking, but that is something that is easily overlooked. The lack of vegetarian options on the room service menu wasn't ideal either but, I suppose one shouldn't be ordering room service whilst in NYC. Will definitely be back!
user_name:
Chevara N
Johannesburg, Gauteng, South Africa

review_body: Weekly traveller to NYC who initially was a 'deer in headlights' working the city - now with the help of the great staff at 6 Columbus- combined with the great location...business life in NYC is great. I dont need any more stress..enough I have to deal with TSA and body searches every week. When I finally get to 6 Columbus..they run to greet you BY NAME [sometimes I cant remember my name...how do they?] They help me find a place to eat based on my mood and my colleagues or business guests...if its raining- umbrellas for all- anything you would expect in a very pricy 4 star hotel they do it every time. I also like the way they upgrade my room if available and mix it up- also placing chocolates or last night a small cupcake. Bottom line is the people...smiles..knowledge and just great to see.

I've stayed in hotels throughout Manhattan at least once a month for the past several years. 6 Columbus, by far, offers the most pleasant, comfortable, and desirable stay of all I've visited. The staff, consistently, is warm and attentive. The location speaks for itself, and with Starbucks next door, Pinkberry a few doors down, and Whole Foods across the street, I am able to enjoy a few hometown favorites in the center of Manhattan. The rooms always are clean and comfortable and are designed for the traveler, with outlets and shelves conveniently located in both the bath and bedroom. The bars on both the first floor and rooftop are comfortable places to relax and have a drink -- well-appointed without any hype. Whatever brings me to Manhattan, knowing I will spend time at 6 Columbus guarantees I will be able to relax in comfort.

The staff at the hotel was extremely nice. When I first arrived at check-in, an upgrade was offered. However, since the upgrade room does not have a bathtub, i have declined it, and stayed with my original reservation. Upon entering the room, when we opened the window, we found a huge air conditional duct right outside. The room, was extremely dark, despite it being sunny outside. The layout of the room was so terrible that it there is really no room to move around, and the only place to sit is a tiny chair, or the bed. For a USD420 a night, this is not worth it at all. The room is not inviting, and after 30minutes in the room, we really did not want to stay in it. We spent 1 night there, and checked out the next day. We went to stay at the Ganvesvoort, much nicer room (one you would actually want to stay in) for about the same price.

1st call I make when planning a visit to NYC. Believe this was the 5th time we stayed and once again couldn't be more pleased with staff and accommodations. Why stay anywhere else. Great location, reasonable price and a staff that makes you feel welcome. More personable than the bigger chain hotels

Booked here through Hotel Tonight. I was given room 89, which by all accounts from their own staff is well known for generating complaints. The a/c did not work but they promised to look at it the next day, but as I was staying one night, no use to me. They suggested that I "open the windows" even though the hotel was like a sauna and due to the location the noise was horrible (and I sleep through anything!). I told them i would not pay for a sauna but they said there was no one to speak to that night. Barely slept due to the excessive heat. Only ipeninf the frint door to create a breeze helpe but i could not leave the door ipen all night. Can you believe this is supposed to be a luxury hotel?!?IIn the morning they said they can make no changes or discounts and said that since the hotel is prepaid with hotel tonight I would have to take it up with them. As we were leaving hotel staff said that people always complain about that room but they keep using it so I appears that they knew beforehand that there were problems with the room and expected complaints but also payment which to me seems simply unethical. Thompson hotels should be embarrassed to claim ownership and management of this property.

I was only in New York for one night & was able to check in a couple hours early which was nice. The location is convenient - however, my room was very disappointing. Not even enough room for a desk or even a small chair --- room only big enough for a bed. Storage is underneath the bed. Minibar food was on window sill --- window looked onto huge pipe & a couple feet away a brick building so unable to even tell if sunny or cloudy out. Room lighting was dark & very loud heat/air system which was hard to regulate. There are better choices.

We stayed for 5 nights and can highly recommend this hotel. We chose it as it is a small boutique hotel in a good location. Right across from Central Park, the subway and within 20 minutes walk to all the midtown attractions. We were lucky enough to be upgraded to a king room on arrival and our room was not huge but sufficient - who is in their room all day anyway. Everything was really clean and each evening we received chocolates and were asked if we needed more ice. You can head over to the Time Warner Centre across the road for coffee/breakfast in the morning. I had a credit card issue and the staff were so helpful in trying to get it sorted for me. We didn't eat at the sushi restaurant downstairs but we did have a drink in the bar - cozy, happening little place. There is also a bar on the rooftop that we went to and it was great as well.

The location was perfect for what I needed - near the Park, many subway lines, Whole Foods, Duane Reade, and tons of restaurants. The Blue Ribbon off the lobby is a great place, and seems less overrun than the downtown locations. The terrace off the Studio Suite I stayed in was a very nice bonus. The tub was large, as was the bathroom itself. Everything was clean. Bed and pillows were comfy. I think I would have been perfectly happy with this place if it didn't tout itself as a luxury hotel with unparalleled service. I have stayed at places like that and the property just didn't live up to those expectations. The Studio Suite was large, but neither a suite nor a studio. You could call the decor "minimalist," I guess, but it just felt sparse, not stylish. The 350-ish-sf room had a king-size bed, closet, TV console/desk, a tiny short side table with 2 chairs...and a ton of unused floor and wall space. There's definitely room for a small loveseat (like you might expect in a suite/studio) or even a single comfortable chair/ottoman setup...there was plenty of seating on the terrace, though! Missing: adequate lighting (I hate harsh lighting, but even by my standards this was very dim, and the bathroom lighting via the round mirror is weird and unflattering. I also couldn't find any lighting for the terrace, which made it difficult to enjoy it at night.), a mirror in the room (only mirror is the round one over the sink the bathroom), a rug (hardwood is nice, but cold on the feet and also noisy), nice shower fixtures (tub stopper was broken, shower felt like stabby needles being shot at my back and was not adjustable), coffee/hot water maker, iron/steamer. I had trouble getting the room to a comfortable temperature -- only heat was available, no cooling -- but maybe it was too early in the season to turn on the HVAC, or maybe I'm just inept! The room doors slam, and do not block smells, sounds, or light. At night, the hallway lights shine through the gaps. I could hear everything going on in the hallway and in other rooms at all hours - I know this is a hotel, but here there was hardly any difference between closing my door and leaving it wide open. My whole floor (and sometimes the lobby) stank of cigarette smoke, and because of the non-sealing doors, the room stank as well. Management was informed of the problem several times but they couldn't get the situation under control. Service was average. No turndown service, though I was there for two nights, and both times I was out of the room during the expected "turndown time."To sum up, this property is in a wonderful location. My stay would have been satisfactory had my expectations not been so high (which I don't think is unreasonable given the advertised prices and amenities). I'd recommend staying here if you get a good deal below their advertised rates.

I booked Columbus for a week for a short visit to NYC. I used to live in NYC and used to go to the Blue Ribbon Sushi often so I decided to give the hotel a shot. Unfortunately, I did not enjoy my stay. When I first checked in I realized that the room were tiny and even worse, the heating system was not working. They sent up the engineer to fix the issue but it still did not work. the next day they moved me to a different room. However, I checked out early and moved to a different hotel. I don't mind the small rooms but the rooms at Columbus just did not feel comfortable. They felt very stuffy and not clean.

6 Columbus is part of the Thompson Hotel chain. The hotel is small, trendy yet very cozy. The location is perfect with nearby shops, 24hr pharmacy/convenience store, starbuck next store, subway stations around the corner, and huge mall across the street filled with shops, and there's even a Wholefoods that opens daily until 11pm. What can I say? Perfect location! Walking distance from great shopping areas such as madison, time square and 5th Avenue. It is also a 30mins cab ride to the Laguardia Airport. Service was excellent. Everyone from the front desk staff, to the concierge, to the guys working at the front door - all were friendly, helpful and pleasant. Rooms are small, but its expected - considered to be NYC standard. Clean and comfy!I highly recommend this hotel and would definitely stay here again.

I have stayed in a lot of NY hotels. Was here on business and it was close to where we needed to be. It is not a bad hotel, it is just nothing special. There are much better hotels in Manhattan. The rooms are very small. I was actually upgraded, which i was appreciative of, but the room was still smaller than others i have stayed at in New York that were standard. I would actually give it 2 1/2 stars but that is not an option. The staff is efficient and polite and the beds were actually comfortable, although is it too much to ask for a sheet or blanket with the comforter? The location is the best. Right off Columbus Circle and near the subway stop.The actual fixtures in the room looked worn out. My ceiling light had a piece of the fabric hanging down that needed to be glued back up. The rooms are very small, so that also means the bathroom are very small. Mirros are rather high up, and not big. So if you are a woman or shorter man you are going to have to stretch to get a good view.And the noise. I just dont know why there has to be constant door slamming by the cleaning crew and the fellow patrons. If you are by the elevator i dont know how you would sleep. Their website advertises Kheils products, which are great, but they actually do not carry them any longer. When asked why their site said so, the front desk said "We need to get that changed on the webiste, it has been a long time since we stopped". Uh ok. Elevators took forever. Just use the stairs. Bottom line if you dont care about sleeping late and just need to crash for a night or two, then this should do the trick. If you are there a prolonged period of time and in room often, dont bother. Much better hotels. Tip: Ask for a room away from elevators. My co-workers had rooms next to and said it was just awful. I had one away but with the door slamming it was not much better on the morning i could sleep in.

I am often in New York, when I am not staying with friends or family I like to try hotels that have been recommended to me so we gave it a go.Now I know rooms in the city are notoriously small and unfortunately this hotel does nothing to dispel the myth but what they lack in inches they make up for in bed comfort and location.The reason for this trip was for a birthday party being held a few blocks away, so we wanted somewhere that was pretty close by and also not to far away from places we were keen on visiting this time round.We arrived and checked in a few days after Hurricane Sandy and even though it was crazy in the JFK arrivals hall, once we got to Manhattan and the hotel itself, we were greeted by sharp professional staff and to bed we went.The rooms are tiny and we didn't have the basic level one but it was ok, as very little time was going to be spent in there. The bathroom is adequate and I even managed to have a bath which sometimes in a NYC shoebox is impossible. Due to Hurricane Sandy the bar that faces Columbus Circle and Central Park was closed, which was a little disappointing as that would have been a nice experience. We went over to the Mandarin Oriental over the street for a great high rise cocktail. Very Nice.One odd thing was that on our floor just as you got out of the elavator, it stank of strong cheese or worse some sort of acidic sick concoction. We did mention it to reception but it was there for the entire duration of our stay.I think I won't be staying here again as there are so many hotels to try in the city.

I stayed at 6 Columbus twice in March of 2013. I thought it was great. Though the standard rooms are a bit small, the suites are spacious. The prices are also surprisingly reasonable for such a stylish hotel in the city. The location of 6 Columbus is fabulous. It's right on Columbus Circle, steps away from Central Park. It's across the street from the Time Warner Center (which has a Whole Foods, plus a whole mall), next door to a Starbucks, and 2 doors down from a Duane Reade, so everything you need is just steps from your front door. The sushi restaurant in the hotel is amazing as well. However, what makes 6 Columbus most special is its staff. Everyone is extremely friendly and very helpful. Linda and Adriana at the front desk were particularly great, as was the concierge, all of the doormen, and the bell hop. Whenever I go back to NY in the future, I will be staying here!

When I arrived I noticed the outer glass of the windows were broken and let the front desk know. They immediately sent someone to check it out, offered me a different room and even called up after I was settled to offer me a free breakfast (didn't use it since my days were packed but it was a nice gesture).
